intro: Thymus wierzbickianus, commonly known as the Polish thyme, is a low-growing perennial herb native to Central and Eastern Europe. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, characterized by square stems and opposite leaves. The plant produces small, tubular flowers that are typically pink to purple in color, which attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Its aromatic foliage contains essential oils, making it useful in culinary and medicinal applications. Thymus wierzbickianus thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, often found in rocky or sandy habitats.
